displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. Huh, my counts, huh, you know, are fine. Things that we’re going to be testing. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. I had the blood test done this morning. Is that what we were reading off for the PSA this morning? Doctor: Yep. Yeah. You might give me a little bit longer than two weeks since you don’t go to Medicare, huh, until, huh, Friday. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yeah. March first it kicks in. I’ve got the card on me if you need it. Family Member: I’ve also got that, our insurance too. Doctor: Okay. So I just emailed the pharmacist to let them know what we’re thinking, huh, to get you started, that’s you’ve switched to Medicare, and that they might end up looking next week. Huh, so hopefully, in the next week or two we’ll know where you are. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, and then, huh, they’ll usually reach out to you about that results. And then, huh, huh, and then I have an appointment if you check out that will coincide with your next shot. Patient: Right. Doctor: Blood work a few days in advance at B___ and a visit with me. So likely that you’re going to be on the abiraterone as you come into that visit. Huh, it’s just an issue of us getting it started. So if you haven’t heard in the next ten days let me know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, because of the Medicare switch, that may be sort of the only delay.

Healthcare Professional: No. Family Member: February is Presidents’ Day? Healthcare Professional: Yeah we’re not – That will be the Monday the nineteenth. Family Member: Right, okay, this is a Tuesday, okay. Doctor: I think even before that we should - Patient: I’m available whenever you – I’ve already alerted - Healthcare Professional: Yes, okay. Doctor: So get in touch with ___ and/or myself. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And let me know that you’re coming actually the week after that. Like as soon as you feel you kinda know and then if we do go down the route of radiation therapy I can refer you to the radiation oncologist here to do that treatment. Patient: Okay, and now what would your role continue to be when I move to another physician? Doctor: Yes, I don’t deliver radiation therapy since I’m a medical oncologist.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it was clear cut growth I’m not gonna keep you on something that’s not helping you. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know I would tell you ditch this and just go get some other treatment. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So for now we gave you the pills for today. Patient: Right. Doctor: So for now you’re okay with keeping on taking it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay and uh we’ll touch base, we’ll let you know of course what the bone scan shows once I look at it. Okay. Family Member 2: Very good. Doctor: Alright. Patient: What do you think. Yeah, Yepthat’s fine.

Patient: Fine. Doctor: Okay. Good to see you. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: A ___ may want you to fill out something, so. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah and where will I get the form for the appointment? Doctor: When you head out front, along that purple wall there there’s people there. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It should be pretty clean and nobody out there now. There might be somebody there and there may not be. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, let me see if A ___ needs to see you before you go. Patient: Okay. Do you have some paperclips? That’s fine. Okay.

Family Member: I’m sorry; say that one more time. You say it’s two? What are the two again? Doctor: The -the two general like avenues that we could go; one is radiotherapy to target that lymph node. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And we have a trial to do that through H__. And the other one is to skip the radiotherapy and go directly to hormone therapy. And then we have a trial looking to see whether combining something with hormone therapy is better than hormone therapy alone. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Well what is the something? Doctor: Something is an oral medication. It’s a new oral hormonal therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a second hormone therapy that given in connection with the injection of hormone therapy we believe may produce better outcomes than just injecting the hormone by itself. Patient: But even with that, that’s still just to slow it down; it’s not to cure anything. It’s kind of take it to add a little bit more Doctor: That’s correct. Everything that we have discussed today frankly is not really curative in terms of its potential. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yes and I like that. During the day see what. Doctor: Yeah, you just see how it, and then, you know, when you take this don’t drive, Patient: Right. Right Doctor: don’t do, I mean and literally don’t drive heavy machinery. Patient: Yeah, I don’t. Doctor: The number of times I’ve had to say that. Wait, so I can’t go out there and work on the tractor? Patient: Right. No. Doctor: No, no, no, right, because you don’t know how you’re going to react. Most people just get sleepy and want to take a nap and then they feel better but everyone’s different. Okay? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Make a copy of this and then. Oh yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Is Provenge off the table? Doctor: Provenge is off the table in the sense that your PSA is um too high I think but more importantly that you have pain. You know, Provenge is good with, it’s kind of like your asymptomatic, you’re doing great, you have a couple spots, your PSA is less than thirty. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Okay will it get curlier? Doctor: It got curlier because the old chemotherapy’s outta your system. Patient: Yeah. (Pause5sec) Family Member: Well, so, if I was your dad, what would you do? Let him have to decide? Doctor: Yeah. I, um, I don’t know – I’ve never made a decision for ya. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue is sort of your sense of what you do to your children, brother, what you want to do. You’re physically well enough. You, you know, if you can think about those things, I think a clinical trial makes a lot of sense. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Or my sense is the other thing is, you know, if time was short, I probably would sort of step back and sort of just focus on, you know, good days. Um. So I would sit there on the fence. I’m not ready to give up on myself. I wanna try something versus -- hhh this has all been too much. (Pause4sec) Patient: If it, it, it extends my, my time that I have to wait for a real cure then maybe it’s worth it. Doctor: Well, that reality is pretty slim. You know, we’ve been working on this awhile, and I’m not sure that a cure is gonna just pop up in the next six months, nine months. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And again, we often, er, don’t have drugs that resurrect people. Uh. You can hope. I hope and pray as well. Uh. The reality is, you know, you can keep pluggin’ along. Uh, so I think you’re eligible because you’re physically well enough to get through this.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Um the reality is that we have tried that in the past and we still do that on occasion in certain patients. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: All the lymph nodes are connected to each other by so-called lymphatic system - Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and so the the the concern about targeting one particular lymph node or maybe two lymph nodes or three lymph nodes is is that um you might only be affecting you know ten percent, fifteen percent, thirty percent of the cancer cells in your body. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So you’re going after them just because you can see it but there is no guarantee that what we can see on the CAT scan is the only place at this point in time where the cancer is at. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: So we might graph that lymph node and your PSA might drop by fifteen percent, then we’ll know in retrospect had we got that lymph node we might have actually killed all of the cells in that lymph node - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and yet your PSA might drop by fifteen or twenty-five percent. And so what we’ve learnt the hard way, so-to-speak with experience, is that although we can do that, it is technically feasible -um and there are some types of radiation that can be reimbursed by insurance companies, for example -

Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay. Doctor: Good. Family Member: I have one more question. Doctor: Yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Because he, when we last saw Dr. V____ in Vegas in July he was telling us there’s some research but it will be seven or eight months out. So that was July so it wouldn’t be until like next month about combining radium with the docetaxel. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so that’s already actually in trial. It is… Family Member: He thought it was better for the body. Doctor: Yeah, it’s not as a home run, you know, there’s nothing that tells me we should do it off road to do that at this moment. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: That’s probably the best way to say it. Nothing that says oh, man, this abstract tells me this is like a home run. No, I think it just adds more side effects. Patient: Yeah, okay, good, okay Doctor: Yeah, so, I know prostate cancer is the one cancer we can’t seem to plot. We love combining stuff. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of- Doctor: Like. No. I think it’s okay. I think K___ has everything. So we’re good. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. I just want to double check. You scared the heck out of me last time. So I’m just gonna I don’t know keep an eye on you just a little bit closer - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: -until I’m confident that I can let you go for three months. Family Member: Right. (Laughter)

Family Member: Open trucks. Doctor: I have a patient, one of my patients is a guy with a lot of money, and he and his wife do this. But, you know, they do it like only people with a lot of money can do it. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: And he’s like, oh, yeah, we’re going and we stay in these tents. Patient: Oh, you can. Doctor: And his wife’s like, yeah, they’re not really tents, though. They like have king-size bed. You know? They’re like- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So they’re like, not like the tent I’ve got. Pop-up and sleep on an air mattress. Patient: They have stuff- Family Member: Right. Patient: They have stuff out there where people can stay out there. I wouldn’t stay out there, man. Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: But if you see something, you’ll call me? Doctor: Yes. If anything changes, we’ll call you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, given your last time’s PSA continued to go down, I’m not too worried. Patient: Okay. Good. You know where I am, right? Doctor: Yeah, from point nine to one point one and you’re feeling good except for your neck. Patient: Yeah. I feel good. Doctor: I just, uh, that is frustrating. I was hoping they would do something to help. Patient: Well, I can always go somewhere else, but you know how that goes. Doctor: Reduce the pressure. Yeah, I wonder if we should have you do that? Patient: It’s, it’s a pain. You know? You know? Why don’t I do that? Doctor: I was wondering if we should get you an appointment with somebody else. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. I was thinking to go down Y___.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 10 years (5 years but le: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 10 years (5 years but less than 10 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.::: strongly disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind::: strongly disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: Is it thirty days as before? In those terms I don’t know- Doctor: We’ll, we’ll see. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Perfect. Doctor: And so I will be in touch by the end of the week to tell you what I’ve, what I’ve learned. Okay? Patient: Alright. Thank you. Doctor: So just for, for now, Germany, I get what they want, the test results, uh, I’ll see what the policy says about you know just paying for, for the drugs. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Can I just inject on the Cornell thing? Clinical trials seem to me like they are very regimen and very time consuming, and I don’t think your situation gives you that. So if you’re willing to do Germany why would you spend this time looking at Germany connection, I mean the Cornell connection, when we’re pretty sure about Germany? I just don’t want to waste your Doctor: Well, you know, if it’s the same drug, which it is, and it’s you know and- Patient: And it’s available. Doctor: You may not care that I’m saving you fifty to hundred thousand dollars but it’s those, those things. Family Member: No. But I’m just very uh the anxiety of the whole thing is, is he - Doctor: I mean the Cornell group has a lot of experience giving you know radioactive compounds, just not for this one, because they’re just starting to do it, so they’ve probably treated a thousand people, maybe they treated three or four hundred people. No wonder that matters. It’s just giving somebody radioactive stuff and making sure after that happens part of it does that big of a difference, uh?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s in a location which is classical and typical for where prostate cancer can typically spread. Patient: Okay then that’s - where is it? Where did you say it went? Doctor: I have to remind myself which side it’s on. It’s on the abdominal - it’s in the abdomen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s too deep to feel, so it’s internal, inside the abdomen. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then.
